natural problem: Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time?
natural solution: Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.

So, in 3 hours, the three good workers will  paint $3(1/4)=3/4$ of my house. The bad workers have to paint the other $1/4$ of the house. Each bad worker paints $1/36$ of the house in an hour, so each bad worker can paint $3(1/36)=1/12$  of the house in three hours.
Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker * x) = 1 / 3"
shows  "x = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.
 So, in 3 hours, the three good workers will  paint $3(1/4)=3/4$ of my house. The bad workers have to paint the other $1/4$ of the house. Each bad worker paints $1/36$ of the house in an hour, so each bad worker can paint $3(1/36)=1/12$  of the house in three hours.
 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.
 *)

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker * x) = 1 / 3"
shows  "x = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A good worker can complete a job in 12 hours, while a bad worker can complete the same job in 36 hours. If three good workers and a certain number of bad workers can complete the job in 3 hours, find the number of bad workers. The final answer is 3.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes good_worker :: real and bad_worker :: real and total_hours :: real and num_good_workers :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "total_hours = 3"
and h3 : "num_good_workers = 3"
shows  "\<exists> num_bad_workers. 1 / total_hours = num_good_workers / good_worker + num_bad_workers / bad_worker"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.
 So, in 3 hours, the three good workers will  paint $3(1/4)=3/4$ of my house. The bad workers have to paint the other $1/4$ of the house. Each bad worker paints $1/36$ of the house in an hour, so each bad worker can paint $3(1/36)=1/12$  of the house in three hours.
 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.
 *)

theorem
fixes good_worker :: real and bad_worker :: real and total_hours :: real and num_good_workers :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "total_hours = 3"
and h3 : "num_good_workers = 3"
shows  "\<exists> num_bad_workers. 1 / total_hours = num_good_workers / good_worker + num_bad_workers / bad_worker"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A good worker can complete a task in 12 hours, while a bad worker takes 36 hours to complete the same task. If 3 good workers work together for 3 hours, how many bad workers are needed to finish the task within the same timeframe?

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker) = 1 / 3"
shows  "bad_worker = 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.

 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.
 *)

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker) = 1 / 3"
shows  "bad_worker = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A good worker can do a job in 12 hours, while a bad worker needs 36 hours to do the same job. If three good workers and one bad worker work together, they can finish the job in 3 hours. How many hours does it take for the bad worker to finish the job alone? The final answer is 3 hours.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes good_workers bad_workers :: nat and work_rate_good work_rate_bad total_work :: real
assumes h0 : "work_rate_good = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "work_rate_bad = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "total_work = 1"
and h3 : "total_work / (3 * work_rate_good + bad_workers * work_rate_bad) \<le> 3"
shows  "bad_workers = 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.
 So, in 3 hours, the three good workers will  paint $3(1/4)=3/4$ of my house. The bad workers have to paint the other $1/4$ of the house. Each bad worker paints $1/36$ of the house in an hour, so each bad worker can paint $3(1/36)=1/12$  of the house in three hours.
 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.
 *)

theorem
fixes good_workers bad_workers :: nat and work_rate_good work_rate_bad total_work :: real
assumes h0 : "work_rate_good = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "work_rate_bad = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "total_work = 1"
and h3 : "total_work / (3 * work_rate_good + bad_workers * work_rate_bad) \<le> 3"
shows  "bad_workers = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A good worker can complete a task in 12 hours, while a bad worker can complete the same task in 36 hours. If the total work to be done is equivalent to one task, and it must be completed in 3 hours or less with the help of 3 good workers and an unknown number of bad workers, how many bad workers are needed? The final answer is 3.

theorem

assumes h0 : "good_worker_rate = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "bad_worker_rate = 1 / 36"

a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3

 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.

theorem
fixes good_worker_rate bad_worker_rate :: real

a_4.informal problem: A good worker can complete a task in 12 hours, while a bad worker takes 36 hours to complete the same task. If three good workers and some number of bad workers can complete the task in 3 hours, how many bad workers are there? The answer is 3.

fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "3 * good_worker + x * bad_worker = 1 / 3"
shows  "x = 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3

 *)

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real

and h1 : "bad_worker = 1 / 36"

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "3 / good_worker + 3 / bad_worker = 1"
shows  "bad_worker = 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3

 *)

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "3 / good_worker + 3 / bad_worker = 1"
shows  "bad_worker = 3"

a_6.informal problem: A good worker can complete a task in 12 hours, and a bad worker can complete the same task in 36 hours. If the two workers work together, they can complete three tasks in a day. Find the time it takes for the bad worker to complete a task. The final answer is 3 hours.

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "3 * good_worker + bad_worker * x = 1 / 3"

a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3

 *)

fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real

and h1 : "bad_worker = 1 / 36"

shows  "x = 3"

a_7.informal problem: A good worker can complete a job in 12 hours, while a bad worker takes 36 hours to complete the same job. If three good workers and some number of bad workers can complete the job in 3 hours, how many bad workers were working? The answer is 3.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes g b :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / 12 * g + 1 / 36 * b = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "g = 3"
shows  "b = 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each good worker can paint my new house alone in 12 hours.  Each bad worker can paint my house alone in 36 hours.  I need my house painted in 3 hours.  If I can only find 3 good workers, how many bad workers must I also find in order to have my house painted on time? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 Each good worker can paint $1/12$ of my house in an hour, so three of them together can  paint $3/12 =1/4$ of my house in an hour.
 So, in 3 hours, the three good workers will  paint $3(1/4)=3/4$ of my house. The bad workers have to paint the other $1/4$ of the house. Each bad worker paints $1/36$ of the house in an hour, so each bad worker can paint $3(1/36)=1/12$  of the house in three hours.
 Since the bad workers together need to paint $1/4$ of the house, and  each bad worker can paint $1/12$ of the house in three hours, I need $(1/4)/(1/12) = \boxed{3}$ bad workers.
 *)

theorem
fixes g b :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / 12 * g + 1 / 36 * b = 1 / 3"
and h1 : "g = 3"
shows  "b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that $g = 3$ and $\frac{1}{12}g + \frac{1}{36}b = \frac{1}{3}$, find the value of $b$. The final answer is $3$.

theorem
fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"
and h1 : "1 / bad_worker = 1 / 36"
and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker * x) = 1 / 3"
shows  "x = 3"
a_9.formal solution:

 *)

fixes good_worker bad_worker :: real
assumes h0 : "1 / good_worker = 1 / 12"

and h2 : "1 / (3 * good_worker + bad_worker * x) = 1 / 3"
shows  "x = 3"

a_9.informal problem: A good worker can complete a task in 12 hours, while a bad worker completes the same task in 36 hours. If 3 good workers and $x$ bad workers working together can complete the task in 3 hours, find the value of $x$. The answer is $x = 3$.
